quotes.topic_title: Opening philosophy: progress, optimism, dissatisfaction
quotes.text: My energy source is dissatisfaction with status quo.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A simple, actionable self-diagnostic for builders: identify and harness what reliably fuels your drive to create change.

quotes.topic_title: Opening philosophy: progress, optimism, dissatisfaction
quotes.text: It behooves us to try to build the kinds of products that leads in ... Towards progress.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A practitioner-oriented north star: treat product-building as a direct lever for progress rather than getting stuck in dystopian narratives.

quotes.topic_title: Opening philosophy: progress, optimism, dissatisfaction
quotes.text: How much is that aesthetic overlapped with outperformance? Pessimism sounds extremely sophisticated. Optimism always sounds dumb or at least naive. The most powerful unquantifiable things in the word of business are fun and delight.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A contrarian critique of “serious” business theater and a reframing that fun and delight can be durable competitive advantages.

quotes.topic_title: Opening philosophy: progress, optimism, dissatisfaction
quotes.text: I talk about look in the future and then think backwards a lot, right? It's like what would we want to have done 20 years ago on this?
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A concrete planning methodology—future-back thinking—that teams can apply to set long-term direction and prioritize present actions.

quotes.topic_title: Opening philosophy: progress, optimism, dissatisfaction
quotes.text: I really, really, really think that there is not a single person on this planet who is even close to being at their maximum potential. Reminding people of their own potential constantly is actually a wonderful thing to do.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A leadership practice: assume massive untapped potential in everyone and make “potential reminders” a recurring part of how you lead.

quotes.topic_title: The 'Tobi tornado' and rapid change management
quotes.text: A Tobi tornado, I would say, is a whole lot of change management or a conversation or conflict or real talk compressed into a very short timeframe.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: Defines a repeatable change-management pattern: deliberately compressing hard conversations and decisions to reduce drag and ambiguity.

quotes.topic_title: The 'Tobi tornado' and rapid change management
quotes.text: At which point a project might be stopped and we get back together in a room and then we start a new version of a product. And everyone who's currently on the team, of that particular project, is no longer on the project but they are the founders of the next version which is built differently.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: Concrete methodology for rapid resets: stop the current effort and reframe the same team as “founders” of the reboot to preserve ownership and momentum.

quotes.topic_title: The 'Tobi tornado' and rapid change management
quotes.text: Again, once I imagine something might be not the right thing to work on I'm either incorrect at which point this is super important that I understand why or I'm correct at which point it's super unfair for letting people work on something that isn't going to make it.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: Decision lens that forces fast clarification: either learn why you’re wrong or stop wasting people’s time if you’re right.

quotes.topic_title: The 'Tobi tornado' and rapid change management
quotes.text: There's a third wave which is I could also ignore it but that's an abjection of my CEO and founder responsibility that I'm absolutely not willing to make so that's just not a path forward that I see valid.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: Contrarian leadership stance: avoiding the hard call is framed as an invalid option and a failure of responsibility.

quotes.topic_title: The 'Tobi tornado' and rapid change management
quotes.text: I think you want to do the maximum amount of things you can be proud of at the end of your career.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A motivating heuristic for prioritization and speed: optimize for career-long pride, not short-term comfort or sunk costs.

quotes.topic_title: Direct feedback as a tool for potential
quotes.text: I really, really, really think that there is not a single person on this planet who is even close to being at their maximum potential.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: Sets a high-expectation premise that justifies direct feedback as a lever for unlocking latent capability.

quotes.topic_title: Direct feedback as a tool for potential
quotes.text: Spending time and longer time in careers with people and then holding them to a high standard means that they accomplish very often things that just they didn't imagine they could.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A practical management method: long-term investment plus high standards expands what people believe they can do.

quotes.topic_title: Direct feedback as a tool for potential
quotes.text: If you are committed to following your curiosity as to the next step, and optimize for maximum amount of learning when you choose these steps, it takes you from one place to another and you actually realize the world's full of lies about human potential and progress.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A decision-making framework: choose next steps by curiosity and learning-maximization to compound growth.

quotes.topic_title: Direct feedback as a tool for potential
quotes.text: School teaches you that you have to learn this particular piece of math in this 12 month period, and it doesn't matter how much you understand it. It's like the outcome can be variable and will grade you on a variable outcome for a fixed amount of time which has nothing to do with anything I've ever seen or learned or see ... Or witnessed about how to actually learn things.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: Challenges conventional education/learning assumptions, implying practitioners should decouple time-boxes from mastery.

quotes.topic_title: Direct feedback as a tool for potential
quotes.text: What I love is an environment of people who are holding each other accountable to the actual potential rather than sort of their current level plus or ... Plus some, I don't know, a little bit extra.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: Defines a cultural operating principle: peer accountability to potential (not baseline performance) as a growth engine.

quotes.topic_title: Learning, school incentives, and curiosity preservation
quotes.text: The biggest problem of this is overfitting, right? What does good look like, a loss function? Which is a heuristic because it's not the actual task that the thing will do in the future it's something that proxies to the task that you want the thing to do in the future. Predict fraud, predict the next word, whatever. So overfitting is basically model learning how to cheat on the benchmark or on the fitness function.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A practical ML-to-life analogy for how proxy metrics can distort behavior away from real-world performance.

quotes.topic_title: Learning, school incentives, and curiosity preservation
quotes.text: Goodhart's law just says, "Any metric that becomes a goal ceases to be a good metric."
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A concise mental model for why optimizing for grades/KPIs can backfire once the metric becomes the target.

quotes.topic_title: Learning, school incentives, and curiosity preservation
quotes.text: School optimizes for what? Marks supposedly, right? In fact, overfitting in school is literally the kids cheating to get marks, right?
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing of cheating as a predictable outcome of metric-optimization rather than purely moral failure.

quotes.topic_title: Learning, school incentives, and curiosity preservation
quotes.text: For us it was just maintaining curiosity. This is a completely different goal from being good at marks.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for parents/leaders: choose an explicit “loss function” (curiosity) instead of defaulting to benchmark outcomes (grades).

quotes.topic_title: Learning, school incentives, and curiosity preservation
quotes.text: Literally, there's a foundation model of a child, and you fine-tune it at school, and it just loses the neurons of curiosity because it's actually discouraged to meander into other topics and explore them just because they're interesting.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A memorable framework using ML fine-tuning to explain how institutional incentives can suppress exploration and intrinsic motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Operating without OKRs: metrics, taste, and Goodhart’s law
quotes.text: Goodhart's law is real. The moment a metric becomes a goal it's no longer a useful metric, right?
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A crisp warning against turning metrics into targets, which can distort decision-making and incentives.

quotes.topic_title: Operating without OKRs: metrics, taste, and Goodhart’s law
quotes.text: It's true that we don't have KPIs and we don't have at least OKRs in the Silicon Valley sense but we are extremely data-informed.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: Clarifies the operating model: avoid OKRs-as-goals while still investing heavily in instrumentation and data access.

quotes.topic_title: Operating without OKRs: metrics, taste, and Goodhart’s law
quotes.text: But I just think the overlap of most valuable things you can do with a product, and for things that happen to be fully quantifiable, it's like maybe 20% which leaves 80% of a value space unaddressable by the people who will only look at quantifiable things.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for balancing quantitative optimization with qualitative judgment like taste, quality, and brand.

quotes.topic_title: Operating without OKRs: metrics, taste, and Goodhart’s law
quotes.text: If people have fun when they're doing something that is just upstream from so ... Sorry, downstream from so many other things. I think that if all the metrics are pointing down but everyone says, "My God, I'm having so much more fun," I think that the very next thing that will happen with some time delay is all metrics will start going up. And if that doesn't happen then we adjust course.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A counterintuitive leading-indicator model: treat fun/delight as upstream signals that can precede metric improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Operating without OKRs: metrics, taste, and Goodhart’s law
quotes.text: I've now actually learned that almost all of the alpha in the world is now in the ... Exactly the things that are unobvious but true. And the things that people dismiss as naive or so.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: Encourages practitioners to seek advantage in ideas that feel unfashionable or “naive” but are directionally correct.

quotes.topic_title: First principles and futurism: designing for the world ahead
quotes.text: Here's the most interesting question I think people can ask builders is like, "What is your energy source? Where are you getting energy from?"
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic for leaders: identify what reliably fuels sustained intensity and performance in yourself/your org.

quotes.topic_title: First principles and futurism: designing for the world ahead
quotes.text: I think fundamentally the world exists at room temperature. Almost all companies are running at that, humming along, doesn't do anything. There are certain individuals who can inject heat into businesses.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A memorable model for why exceptional companies outperform: they have leaders who actively add energy rather than passively maintain equilibrium.

quotes.topic_title: First principles and futurism: designing for the world ahead
quotes.text: I am not... My energy source is dissatisfaction with status quo.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A concrete, transferable leadership lever: channel dissatisfaction into momentum for change and building.

quotes.topic_title: First principles and futurism: designing for the world ahead
quotes.text: But yes, I think if someone comes to me and says, "Hey, let's go do this thing. And we've looked around and here's how people solve this problem, let's make a good version of that," I'm like, "That was not the job."
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A contrarian stance against benchmarking-as-strategy: copying incumbents is framed as missing the real product leadership work.

quotes.topic_title: First principles and futurism: designing for the world ahead
quotes.text: So I think what you have to do is to actually have, when you come up with a new product or you discuss a new product, you have to derive it from first principles. You have to say, "How would we solve this problem given every fundamental building block that we have available right now?"
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology for product design: start from current “atomic” capabilities rather than inherited, path-dependent patterns.

quotes.topic_title: Examples of first principles: Shopify’s origin and search rebuilds
quotes.text: If you want to do something better than what exists, you have to do it differently.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A first-principles axiom for innovation: “better” requires “different,” not incremental imitation.

quotes.topic_title: Examples of first principles: Shopify’s origin and search rebuilds
quotes.text: I think this is entirely learnable, I think. And so I encourage people to just have a practice of think step by step essentially and just do it. It'll become a habit pretty quickly because it just, it also just outperforms.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: Practical advice that first-principles thinking is a trainable habit built through step-by-step reasoning.

quotes.topic_title: Examples of first principles: Shopify’s origin and search rebuilds
quotes.text: I wanted to make e-commerce software that would do very well on the internet of the future and I believe that we can make it easier to start new businesses online than it is in a physical world because the physical world is encumbered by a lot of regulations and also upfront costs for leases and so on.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A concrete example of choosing a first-principles target user and environment (internet-native entrepreneurs) rather than inheriting legacy constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Examples of first principles: Shopify’s origin and search rebuilds
quotes.text: Enterprise software is overfit to the sales process, which is that it wins the RFPs because it has every feature ever or at least a way of putting a checkbox next to every RFP line ever. But they're not good, right?
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A contrarian critique that “feature completeness” is often an artifact of procurement incentives, not software quality.

quotes.topic_title: Examples of first principles: Shopify’s origin and search rebuilds
quotes.text: I think we've been in a local maxima on search and we think that, especially with the advances of the new models, certain things are now possible to do that could not have been done yet because again of these layers and layers of path dependence and no one coming and saying, "Is that the best way to do and maybe we should rebuild this component periodically?"
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A methodology for periodically re-evaluating core systems to escape local maxima as technology shifts.

quotes.topic_title: Re-running decisions like code: remote-work pivot
quotes.text: You make you re-derive literally every decision that is valuable, every foundational assumption, every foundational ABC direction. And you want to see the observation you've made in the meantime since you last derived the next step. Re-running the entire function over the state that is now updated, the higher fidelity information, would you come to the very same thing?
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A practical decision-making framework: periodically re-run key decisions from first principles using updated inputs to see if you’d still choose the same path.

quotes.topic_title: Re-running decisions like code: remote-work pivot
quotes.text: The moment that flips, it's not that just like, "Okay, over here let's do the best what we can do." It's actually that the entire tree now moves into a different place. And it can be a very far place, different, that you land because you will make the same quality of decision on every step, but you need to rerun something that takes you to a completely different landing zone.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A mental model for pivots: when a foundational assumption changes, you should expect the optimal strategy to jump to a totally different “landing zone,” not just adjust locally.

quotes.topic_title: Re-running decisions like code: remote-work pivot
quotes.text: Most of the time you end up in a bad part of a tree, in a local maxima of a path-dependent environment, by only making good choices. People think that making a good choice inoculates you from making mistakes or that the presence of a downside of an idea ends up disqualifying the idea. Both of those things are incorrect.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning: consistently “good” incremental decisions can still trap you in a suboptimal local maximum, so you must periodically reassess the whole decision tree.

quotes.topic_title: Re-running decisions like code: remote-work pivot
quotes.text: So anyone who runs this optimization function I'm talking about here about location strategy for a new startup will come to the conclusion if they do it right that everyone should be sitting around the same table. Only if you can't do that, do you say, "Okay, let's be all in the same couple of rooms." Only if that doesn't work anymore, you say, "Okay, let's be spread over one floor." If that doesn't work, in the same building. If that doesn't work, in the same city. If that doesn't work, at least stay in the same time zones or make sure that there's good hub connections between.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A concrete, stepwise “collocation ladder” for org/location strategy that teams can apply when deciding how distributed to be.

quotes.topic_title: Re-running decisions like code: remote-work pivot
quotes.text: Even with this decision, it's a better set of trade-offs for the future is to accept the vast additional difficulty of building a remote company. It's way harder.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A strategic trade-off principle: remote-first can be the better long-term choice even when it’s significantly harder operationally.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Loom can help you have fewer meetings and make the meetings that you do have much more productive.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable productivity advice: use async video to reduce meeting load while improving the quality of the meetings that remain.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Meetings start with everyone on the same page and end early.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete operational outcome to aim for when adopting async updates: better pre-alignment shortens meetings.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: That's my happy place, being able to clear out free days of my calendar and being there till midnight with all these remarkable people who join us on journey, just building stuff.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A memorable leadership model: protect deep work time and stay close to the craft alongside the team.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's like, I do my job so that that is the jobs that exist for other people.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A counterintuitive framing of leadership as creating the conditions for others to do the work you value most.

quotes.topic_title: Why Tobi still codes: craft, closeness to the metal
quotes.text: I try to sanity-check as much as I can of what I get. I try to find... It's a game for me to find new insights in data.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A practical habit: use hands-on work and data exploration to validate ideas and surface insights rather than relying on abstractions.

quotes.topic_title: Why Tobi still codes: craft, closeness to the metal
quotes.text: First principles thinking starts from, I think Elon puts it as physics, which I think is a little bit atoms-coded. I think just from the atomic building blocks really is a right starting point.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A memorable framing of first-principles thinking as starting from the smallest real components of the system you’re working in.

quotes.topic_title: Why Tobi still codes: craft, closeness to the metal
quotes.text: Atomic building blocks are the computers we are using. Computers are our instruments. We use them to create the music that when people appreciate to receive in the form of software.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A vivid mental model: treat computers as instruments and software as the “music,” emphasizing craft and mastery of the underlying tool.

quotes.topic_title: Why Tobi still codes: craft, closeness to the metal
quotes.text: So you've got to understand how they work, at least to work the way I do.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: Direct guidance that effective first-principles leadership in software requires understanding the underlying implementation details.

quotes.topic_title: Engineering strategy decisions: monorepo, sunk costs, changing minds
quotes.text: Atomic building blocks are the computers we are using. Computers are our instruments. We use them to create the music that when people appreciate to receive in the form of software. So you've got to understand how they work, at least to work the way I do.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A first-principles framing for software leadership: treat computers as the fundamental “instrument” and deeply understand them to make better decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Engineering strategy decisions: monorepo, sunk costs, changing minds
quotes.text: And so what I learned works is be in as many details as you can. Really, really, really just understand the stuff that we are making decisions about and be willing to don't put too much stake into the sunk cost fallacy. Try to inoculate business or your parts of a company from a sunk cost fallacy as much as possible because that allows you to just see better solutions and so on.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: Actionable operating advice: go deep on the details and actively design against sunk-cost thinking to unlock better options.

quotes.topic_title: Engineering strategy decisions: monorepo, sunk costs, changing minds
quotes.text: Again, monorepo, now for companies, it's a very much one of those door A, door B kind of things. It's a very consequential choice that is incorrect to go say yes to at a certain size, and then it becomes very correct in my mind to say yes to, but at that point it's an enormous amount of effort.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A counterintuitive strategy point: some architecture decisions flip from “wrong” to “right” as scale changes, but become far costlier later.

quotes.topic_title: Engineering strategy decisions: monorepo, sunk costs, changing minds
quotes.text: Everyone can come to me with better ideas about anything, and if you're right, I will change my mind. But I will hold my opinions very strongly until the point of being convinced that they're not the correct ideas.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A leadership methodology for decision-making: strong convictions paired with rapid updating when presented with better evidence.

quotes.topic_title: Engineering strategy decisions: monorepo, sunk costs, changing minds
quotes.text: Although, I'm more of a Maynard Keynes school of... "When the facts change, I change my opinion. What do you do, sir?" It sounds like a better OS to go by.
quotes.speaker: Tobi Lütke
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that challenges “consistency” as a virtue, prioritizing truth-seeking and adaptability instead.
